messages.content: Dharma (धर्म) is one of the most profound concepts in Hindu philosophy. It has multiple meanings: (1) Righteousness and moral duty, (2) The cosmic law that maintains order, (3) One's personal duty based on their stage of life and position. The Bhagavad Gita teaches 'svadharma' - following one's own dharma is better than another's dharma well-performed. Dharma is what holds together society and the cosmos.

Karma Yoga is the path of selfless action taught prominently in the Bhagavad Gita. Its essence is captured in verse 2.47: 'कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन' - 'You have a right to perform your duty, but not to the fruits of action.' Key principles: (1) Perform your duty without attachment, (2) Don't be motivated by results, (3) Maintain equanimity in success and failure, (4) Offer all actions to the Divine. This transforms work into worship and liberates one from bondage.

Atman (आत्मन्) is the eternal, unchanging Self - the true essence of every being. The Katha Upanishad beautifully describes it: 'न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन्' - 'It is never born nor does it die.' Key teachings: (1) Atman is distinct from the body and mind, (2) It is identical with Brahman (the Absolute), (3) It is consciousness itself, (4) Realizing 'I am Atman' is liberation (moksha). The Chandogya Upanishad teaches 'Tat Tvam Asi' - 'That thou art' - affirming this identity.

Based on Patanjali's Yoga Sutras, here's a systematic approach: (1) **Yama & Niyama**: Practice ethical disciplines first, (2) **Asana**: Find a comfortable, steady posture, (3) **Pranayama**: Begin with simple breath awareness, (4) **Pratyahara**: Withdraw senses from external objects, (5) **Dharana**: Focus on one point (breath, mantra, or deity). Start with 5-10 minutes daily. The key sutra is 1.2: 'योगश्चित्तवृत्तिनिरोधः' - Yoga is the cessation of mental modifications. Be patient and consistent.

Om (ॐ) is the primordial sound, the cosmic vibration from which all creation emerges. The Mandukya Upanishad is devoted entirely to Om, stating: 'ॐ इत्येतदक्षरमिदं सर्वम्' - 'Om is this imperishable syllable, it is all this.' Om has three parts: (1) A (अ) - waking state, creation, Brahma, (2) U (उ) - dream state, preservation, Vishnu, (3) M (म) - deep sleep, dissolution, Shiva. The silence after represents Turiya - the fourth state of pure consciousness. Chanting Om aligns us with cosmic vibrations.

Hindu philosophy offers detailed teachings on death and rebirth. The Bhagavad Gita (2.22) states: 'वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि' - 'As one discards worn-out clothes and wears new ones, so the soul discards worn-out bodies and enters new ones.' Key concepts: (1) **Karma**: Actions determine next birth, (2) **Samsara**: Cycle of birth-death-rebirth, (3) **Moksha**: Liberation from the cycle, (4) **Pitr-loka**: Ancestral realm. The soul (Atman) is eternal; only the body changes.

Maya (माया) is the cosmic illusion that makes the temporary appear permanent and the unreal appear real. Adi Shankaracharya's Advaita Vedanta explains: Maya causes us to see multiplicity where there is only Brahman (unity). It has two powers: (1) **Avarana Shakti**: Veiling power - hides the true nature of reality, (2) **Vikshepa Shakti**: Projecting power - projects the world of names and forms. Maya is neither real nor unreal - it's indescribable. Knowledge (jnana) of Brahman destroys Maya's effect.
